Award.AwardTitle: Testing the Lambda Cold Dark Matter Model with Dwarf Galaxies around the Milky Way and beyond
Award.AbstractNarration: Burcin Mutlu is awarded an NSF Astronomy and Astrophysics Postdoctoral Fellowship to conduct a program of research and education at the University of Chicago. She will use new and existing observations to study faint small galaxies known as "dwarf galaxies" orbiting the Milky Way and nearby galaxies. Because the faintest dwarf galaxies contain the largest fraction of dark matter by mass, they are excellent laboratories in which to study the influence of dark matter on the formation and growth of galaxies. Results from this project will allow astronomers to understand how galaxies form and grow from the smallest structures. Along with this research, Mutlu will conduct a mentoring program to increase the retention of underrepresented students in science.<br/><br/>This project will advance our understanding of how galaxies form at the lowest mass scales. By detecting nearly two dozen new dwarf galaxies, it will extend the census of the faintest dwarf satellite population of the Milky Way, as well as similar nearby galaxies, allowing an investigation of the properties of dwarf galaxies as a function of the environment and primary halo mass. Observational trends from this study would allow astronomers to assess whether the Lambda Cold Dark Matter model holds at the lowest mass scales, and whether a more detailed treatment of baryonic physics is required in the model.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Λ Cold Dark Matter model is very successful in reproducing large-scale structures, but challenges remain on small scales where straightforward expectations for the properties of dwarf galaxies are not met, demonstrating our incomplete understanding of the physics of galaxy evolution. The solution could lie in baryonic physics, details of dark matter physics, and perhaps exotic alternative models, and we can test these potential explanations by checking how ubiquitous the small-scale problems are, and whether there is dependence on primary galaxy-halo properties and/or the environments that galaxies were born into. PI proposed to do this test by discovering and characterizing dwarf galaxies around the Milky Way (MW) and other nearby galaxies, in order to reach a better understanding of the physics that regulates galaxy evolution at the smallest scales. 

This research program established a more complete census of the faintest dwarf satellite population of the Milky Way, provided the first robust probe of dwarf satellite population around an MW-mass galaxy in a very low-density environment, and resulted in a detailed examination of two faint dwarf satellites of two LMC-mass galaxies. This project yielded the first confirmed ultra-faint dwarf satellite galaxies of an MW-mass galaxy beyond the Local Group. It also projected the path of resolved searches for faint dwarf galaxies in the Local Volume for the coming decade. This program also supported a diversity-related mentoring program, to provide a mechanism for underrepresented students to come together and collectively work to address issues that inhibit their academic success.
